chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of pubic lice
chapter.summary: Covers the management and treatment of people presenting with pubic lice infestation, including people who have failed to respond to an initial course of insecticide treatment.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 6 months onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How is pubic lice infestation managed in primary care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Provide oral and written information on pubic lice infestation and treatment.
    • Ensure that the person is aware that treatment may fail if specific regimen instructions are not closely followed.
    • Patient information is available from:
      • Family Planning Association "Pubic lice and scabies".
      • NHS A-Z "Pubic lice".
  • Advise the person to:
    • Decontaminate clothes and bed linen by washing items in hot water (50oC or more), dry cleaning or placing them in a sealed plastic bag for at least a week to kill the lice — mattresses should be vacuumed.
    • Avoid close body contact, sexual contact and sharing of clothes, bedding and personal hygiene products until they (and their partner[s]) have successfully completed treatment.
  • For lice on body areas other than the eyelids, treat with an appropriate topical insecticide:
    • Advise the person to apply the cream, lotion or shampoo exactly as recommended by the specific product instructions. For guidance on prescribing see the British National Formulary and the Prescribing section. Options for topical treatments include:
      • Permethrin cream — apply to the whole body, allow to dry and wash off after 12 hours.
      • Malathion 0.5% aqueous solution — apply to all surfaces of the body and wash off after at least 2 (preferably 12) hours.
    • Advise the person to reapply the treatment 7 days after initial application to ensure that lice emerging from surviving eggs are eradicated.
    • Explain that pruritus may persist for several days or weeks after treatment, especially if skin is excoriated.
    • Dead lice and nits can be removed with a fine toothed comb.
  • For lice on eyelashes:
    • Depending on the clinical situation treat pubic lice infestation of the eye lashes with either inert occlusive ophthalmic ointment or permethrin 1% lotion.
      • Inert occlusive ophthalmic ointments should be used for people under the age of 18 years, and for those who are pregnant or breastfeeding.
      • Occlusive ophthalmic ointment should be applied to the eyelid margins twice a day for 10 days.
      • If permethrin 1% lotion is appropriate the person should be advised to apply the product to the eyelashes keeping the eyes closed during application and wash off after 10 minutes.
  • If the infestation is thought to have been acquired through sexual contact:
    • Refer adults and adolescents to a genito-urinary medicine (GUM) clinic for screening for other sexually transmitted infections and contact tracing unless facilities and appropriate expertise are available locally.
  • Consider the possibility of sexual abuse in children with pubic lice.
    • The presence of pubic lice in children does not always indicate sexual abuse or sexual activity as transmission can occur through non-genital contact between close household contacts and shared bedding or clothing.
    • For more information, see the CKS topic on Child maltreatment - recognition and management.
  • Follow up:
    • Re-examine the person 1 week after completion of treatment to ensure that all lice have been killed.
      • Dead nits can remain attached to hairs and this does not indicate treatment failure — nits can be removed with a fine-toothed ‘nit’ comb.
    • If live lice are seen at follow up, re-treat with an alternative regimen.
  • Refer to or discuss with a specialist (GUM) if:
    • Treatment fails despite the use of an alternative regimen or uncertain about management or treatment.
    • The clinical picture is atypical — the diagnosis may need to be reconsidered. Referral to GUM or a dermatologist may be indicated.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Recommendations on the management of a person with pubic lice infestation are based on the clinical guidelines United Kingdom National Guideline on the Management of Phthirus pubis infestation (2007) [BASHH, 2007], Canadian guidelines on sexually transmitted infections. Management and treatment of specific infections - ectoparasitic infestations [Public Health Agency of Canada, 2013], Sexually transmitted infections in primary care [RCGP, 2013], 2015 Sexually transmitted diseases treatment guidelines. Ectoparasitic infections: pediculosis pubis [CDC, 2015], Pubic lice [Primary Care Dermatology Society, 2015], and European guideline for the management of pediculosis pubis [Salavastru, 2017] and expert opinion in review articles [Gunning, 2012; Markova, 2014; Dadabhoy, 2015; Sangare, 2016].

Wash clothing and bed linen at 50oC
  • Lice have been found on clothing, towels, and sheets - clinical guidelines [RCGP, 2013], [CDC, 2015] and [Salavastru, 2017] expert opinion in review articles [Gunning, 2012; Sangare, 2016] recommend washing at high temperature (at least 122°F (50oC) to eradicate lice.
Topical treatments
  • There are few quality data comparing the available treatments of pediculosis pubis and most recent studies relate to treatment of pediculosis capitis [Salavastru, 2017].
  • Pregnancy and breastfeeding:
    • The UK Medicines Information (UKMi) for NHS professionals could find no studies relating to the passage of topically applied malathion or permethrin into human breast milk. Percutaneous absorption of malathion is about 4% and it is rapidly destroyed by plasma cholinesterases. Percutaneous absorption of permethrin is less than 2% and it is rapidly metabolised to inactive metabolites and excreted in the urine. UKMi theorise that the amount of drug passing into milk after topical application would be too low to present a hazard to the breastfeeding infant and conclude that either malathion or permethrin topical preparations may be used to treat pubic lice infestations in breastfeeding mothers of full term, healthy infants [UKMi, 2015].
    • Clinical guidelines from the British Association of Sexual Health and HIV [BASHH, 2007], Centres for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC, 2015] and the European Academy of Dermatology and Venereology [Salavastru, 2017] state that permethrin can be used in pregnancy and breastfeeding.
    • The UK Teratology Information Service (UKTIS) has issued a monograph relating to permethrin and malathion use in treatment of scabies in pregnancy. This states that neither is licensed for use during pregnancy or breastfeeding. Available pregnancy safety data is limited and does not provide evidence that either product poses an increased risk to the foetus. It is noted that most of the data on malathion relates to environmental exposure to crop sprays and may not reflect the risks for short-term topical use. UKTIS conclude that available data for both malathion and permethrin are too limited to state that there is no risk [UKTIS, 2013].
Treatment of lice on eyelashes
  • Recommendations from the UK, European and North American guidelines on treatment of lice on eyelashes are conflicting:
    • The Royal College of General Practitioners and British Association of Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) and European Academy of Dermatology and Venereology [BASHH, 2007; RCGP, 2013; Salavastru, 2017] guidelines state that infestation of eyelashes can be treated with permethrin 1% lotion keeping the eyes closed during the 10 minute application or alternatively, paraffin eye ointment can be used topically twice a day for 8-10 days.
    • The Public Health Agency of Canada [Public Health Agency of Canada, 2013] and the Centres for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC, 2015] state that pediculosis of the eyelashes should be treated by applying occlusive ophthalmic ointment or petroleum jelly to the eyelid margins twice a day for 10 days and should not be treated with permethrin, pyrethrin or lindane.
  • Paraffin eye ointment is effective by suffocating adult lice and nymphs (immature lice) [RCGP, 2013; Salavastru, 2017].
    • An inert ophthalmic ointment with a white or yellow soft paraffin base provides a suitable consistency to produce this effect.
    • Inert ophthalmic ointments are preferred over topical ointments that are not formulated for use in the eyes because there is no risk of adverse effects should the ointment spread to the eye. In addition, ophthalmic ointments are sterile prior to use, reducing risk of eye infection.
Reapply treatment 7-10 days are initial treatment
  • Persistent infestation is found in 40% of the patients 10 days after treatment and nit combing. Reapplication of treatment after 7-10 days can kill adult lice emerging from eggs that have survived the initial treatment [Salavastru, 2017].
Refer to genito-urinary medicine (GUM) if infestation is thought to have been acquired through sexual contact
  • All identified guidelines and expert reviewers recommend appropriate screening for and treatment of concomitant sexually transmitted infections along with partner notification.
    • The 2012 BASHH statement on partner notification for sexually transmissible infections [McClean, 2013] states that healthcare workers providing partner notification should have documented and appropriate competencies.
Consider abuse in children with pubic lice infestation
  • The presence of pubic lice infestation in children is not necessarily an indicator of sexual abuse or sexual activity as lice can be transmitted by non-genital bodily contact between household contacts but should be considered in all cases [Salavastru, 2017].
Persistent infestation
  • Reported resistance to pediculicides (permethrin and pyrethrins) has been increasing and is widespread [CDC, 2015].
  • Several clinical guidelines and expert reviewers recommend retreatment with an alternative regimen if live lice are seen at 1 weeks follow up [RCGP, 2013; CDC, 2015; Salavastru, 2017].
    • Clearance of infestation can be confirmed if 1 week after the end of treatment no live lice are present [Salavastru, 2017].
